newsitem.title: USA: Oil prices fall back as Iraqi troops withdraw.
newsitem.headline: Oil prices fall back as Iraqi troops withdraw.

text.p: Oil prices closed lower Wednesday after Iraqi troops withdrew from some Kurdish areas in northern Iraq and President Clinton said immediate U.S. goals had been met after a second missile attack on Iraqi military targets.
At the New York Mercatile Exchange October crude oil futures closed 16 cents a barrel lower at $23.24 and October heating oil closed 0.86 cent a gallon lower at 64.21 cents.
Selling was restrained by continued uncertainty about the Iraqi situation and other factors such as Hurricane Fran, a massive storm threatening the mid-Atlantic seaboard.
October unleaded gasoline ended unchanged at 62.96 cents per gallon.

"It was a combination of the uncertainty and the fundamentals. We are still not getting 700,000 barrels," said Rita Beale, an analyst with Fimat USA Futures, of the limited sell-off in futures on news of the Iraqi troop withdrawal.
"The uptrend is still in place," Beale said.
Iraq was expected to start providing 700,000 barrels a day of crude to world markets later this month under a United Nations deal to sell oil to buy food and medicine.
That deal was frozen indefinitely over the weekend after Iraqi troops attacked Kurdish groups in a move that prompted U.S. cruise missile attacks on Iraqi radar and other installations.
Analysts also pointed to underlying heating oil demand and tight crude oil stocks as reasons to keep the oil market firm.
The American Petroleum Institute reported after the close of trading that U.S. crude oil stocks fell 5.68 million barrels in the week ended Aug. 30 to 313.15 million barrels.
Gasoline stocks fell 3.71 million barrels to 192.82 million from 196.53 million barrels but distillate or heating oil stocks rose 3.24 million barrels to 108.90 million.

At the Commodity Exchange, December copper closed 1.45 cents per pound lower at 94.40 cents per pound following a sharp sell-off on the London Metal Exchange. But analysts said a rebound could occur due to a possible mine strike.

Union officials negotiating for a new contract at Phelps Dodge Corp.'s Chino, N.M., mine said Wednesday that talks were at a stalemate. The contract for 670 workers at the 170,000-ton-per-year mine expired on June 30.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, improved sentiment about this year's corn and soybean crops pushed prices lower.
November soybeans closed 15-1/4 cents per bushel lower at $7.80-1/4, and December corn ended 8 cents per bushel lower at $3.33-1/2.
Iowa-based Farmers Commodities Corp. late Tuesday predicted the U.S. soybean crop would total 2.276 billion bushels, up slightly from its previous guess of 2.271 billion.
FCC also pegged the corn crop at 9.02 billion bushels, below its previous 9.081 billion but well above last month's forecast by the Agriculture Department at 8.695 billion.
"It was a reality check today for the market from FCC," said analyst Vic Lespinasse of Dean Witter Reynolds.
At the New York Cotton Exchange prices fell back as Hurricane Fran looked set to avoid any major damage to southern crops. December cotton closed down 1.63 cents at 75.62 cents a pound.
